G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as applicable), which authorizes the Court to modify custody and parenting time orders upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where such modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 (and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as applicable), which authorizes the Court to modify custody and parenting time orders upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where such modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition:
COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION OF CUSTODY / PARENTING TIME ORDER
(G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 208.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6, and applicable provisions of G.L. c. 208 and/or G.L. c. 209C (as applicable to the underlying judgment), as this Court issued the existing custody and parenting time order concerning the Children on June 15, 2021.

G.L. c. 209C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6, and applicable provisions of G.L. c. 208 and/or G.L. c. 209C (as applicable to the underlying judgment), as this Court issued the existing custody and parenting time order concerning the Children on June 15, 2021.

28 U.S.C. \u00a7 1738A.proposition: The Children have resided in Massachusetts at all relevant times, and Massachusetts is their home state within the meaning of the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction statutes and the federal Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act, 28 U.S.C. § 1738A.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Defendant’s cohabitation with the Cohabitant, who has a documented history of violence and court-involved abusive behavior, did not exist and was not contemplated at the time of the 2021 Judgment, and therefore represents a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 28; Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (material change in circumstances standard); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599–600 (1996).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion in Bouchard does not discuss modification of prior custody or support judgments, material change in circumstances, or post‑judgment cohabitation. It addresses only the standards and required findings for an initial custody determination, emphasizing that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and a weighing of all relevant factors. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition that later-arising cohabitation with an abusive partner constitutes a material change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599\t6.proposition: The Defendant’s cohabitation with the Cohabitant, who has a documented history of violence and court-involved abusive behavior, did not exist and was not contemplated at the time of the 2021 Judgment, and therefore represents a material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 28; Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (material change in circumstances standard); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599	600 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599\t6.support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn does not address the material-change-in-circumstances standard for modifying an existing custody judgment, nor does it deal with postjudgment cohabitation with a violent partner. The case concerns an appeal from an initial custody judgment and focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its impact on the child, not on whether new circumstances arising after a prior judgment constitute a material change. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599\t6.relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ ... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking."

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that exposure of minor children to domestic violence, abuse, or a household environment marked by aggression and volatility is a critical factor in custody and parenting-time determinations.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is an extended discussion of the best-interests standard, primary caregiver, and stability considerations in custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). It does not address domestic violence, abuse, or exposure to an aggressive or volatile household, nor does it identify such exposure as a factor in deciding custody or parenting time. Because the case does not mention or analyze domestic violence or household aggression at all, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is “best for the child” is firmly rooted in American history... If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.

Custody of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988).proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that exposure of minor children to domestic violence, abuse, or a household environment marked by aggression and volatility is a critical factor in custody and parenting-time determinations.
Custody of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns procedural issues in a care-and-protection proceeding (who may prosecute the case and the impropriety of the judge’s reliance on extra-record information). It does not analyze or articulate any principle that exposure of a child to domestic violence or a violent household is a critical factor in custody or parenting-time determinations. The only mention of violence is incidental and expressly not contested on appeal, and the court offers no doctrinal discussion about the significance of domestic violence to custody outcomes.
Custody of Benjamin, 403 Mass. 24 (1988).relevant_excerpt: "The judge found that the man had 'shown violent actions in the past . . . and continues to do so until recently including the beating perpetrated against the child.' ... On appeal she makes no argument that her unfitness cannot properly be based on the fact that she was living with a man who was a threat to Benjamin."

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10.proposition: The Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement provisions and general Massachusetts family law mandate that the child’s best interests are paramount in any parenting-time determination.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement provisions and general Massachusetts family law mandate that the child’s best interests are paramount in any parenting-time determination.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement provisions and general Massachusetts family law mandate that the child’s best interests are paramount in any parenting-time determination.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that under the Massachusetts removal statute the phrase “upon cause shown” means removal must be in the best interests of the child, and repeatedly emphasizes that the best interests of the children are the paramount concern in custody and removal decisions. Although the case involves relocation rather than routine parenting-time schedules, the court frames the entire custody and visitation/removal analysis around the child’s best interests, making clear that this standard governs such family law determinations in Massachusetts.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … [a] minor child … shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”}

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\t6.proposition: The Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement provisions and general Massachusetts family law mandate that the child’s best interests are paramount in any parenting-time determination.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\t6.support_reasoning: The concurrence focuses on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute (G.L. c. 209C) and on the mother’s sole custodial rights prior to adjudication of paternity, not on the Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement provisions generally or a broad rule that best interests are always paramount in any parenting-time determination. While it references best interests and stability (citing Custody of Kali), it does so in the context of criticizing the judge’s improper use of a relocation analysis and enforcing the statutory scheme, rather than articulating a general, overarching mandate about best interests controlling every parenting-time decision. The proposition overreads the opinion’s scope.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 547\t6.relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ('If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement...')."

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31A, and related jurisprudence, the Court must give particular weight to evidence of past or present abuse, the safety and well-being of the child, and the safety of the abused parent, and must fashion custody and visitation arrangements that do not expose the child to a substantial risk of harm.

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\t63.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have recognized that a child’s environment, including exposure to violent or abusive individuals in the household, is a critical factor in the best-interests analysis and can warrant modification of custody or parenting time.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\t63.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a noncustodial parent’s religious instruction (as a Jehovah’s Witness) can justify restricting visitation absent proof of harm; it does not discuss exposure to violence or abusive individuals in the household. The opinion focuses on religious differences, evidentiary standards for showing emotional or physical harm, and best-interests analysis in that specific context, not on environmental danger or abuse warranting modification of custody or parenting time. It therefore does not support the specific proposition about exposure to violent or abusive individuals as a critical best-interests factor.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\t63.relevant_excerpt: “In all events, the question that comes to the courts is whether, in particular circumstances, such exposures are disturbing a child to its substantial injury, physical or emotional, and will have a like harmful tendency for the future… Thus there is clear error, for lack of foundation in the record, in the judge’s findings of a ‘deleterious effect’ on the children and an ‘undermining’ of the custodial relationship by reason of the father’s religious instruction or practice.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\t62.proposition: The changed circumstances described above directly implicate the Children’s safety, physical integrity, and emotional health, and therefore go to the heart of the best-interests analysis. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842	644; Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225	626 (1998).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\t62.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that certain changed circumstances directly implicate the children’s safety, physical integrity, and emotional health and therefore go to the heart of the best-interests analysis. Adoption of Hugo does discuss and apply a best-interests standard, but it does not frame or analyze the case in terms of ‘changed circumstances’ that directly implicate safety, physical integrity, and emotional health in the way the proposition describes. Instead, the opinion focuses on comparing two stable adoptive placements and weighing long-term developmental prospects versus the trauma of separation, without articulating the specific principle quoted in the proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\t62.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability… with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”}

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts case law consistently applies this two-part test. See, e.g.:
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The quoted opinion discusses the governing principle in custody cases (the welfare/best interests of the child) and the need to weigh all relevant factors; it does not articulate or apply any explicit ‘two-part test.’ Because the proposition refers to a specific two-part test and claims Massachusetts case law consistently applies it, and this opinion does not describe such a test, the case does not meaningfully support that proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 765\t.proposition: Massachusetts case law consistently applies this two-part test. See, e.g.:
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 765\t.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that Massachusetts case law consistently applies a specific two-part test, but the excerpt from Custody of a Minor (1983) does not articulate any explicit two-part test, nor does it describe Massachusetts law in those ‘two-part’ terms. Instead, the opinion discusses the parental unfitness standard, best interests, evidentiary burden, and procedural issues. Because no distinct two-part test is identified or endorsed in the quoted text, the case does not support the proposition as phrased.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 765\t.relevant_excerpt: “State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection. In that sense, the fitness of parents and the best interests of the child are related. … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404	605 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Massachusetts case law consistently applies this two-part test. See, e.g.:
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The proposition refers to a “two-part test,” but the excerpt from Rolde does not articulate or apply any explicit two-part test, nor does it describe Massachusetts law as consistently applying such a test. The opinion discusses standards for division of marital assets under G.L. c. 208, § 34 and the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in custody, but no specific two-part framework is identified. Without the missing context of what the two-part test is, this case, as quoted, cannot be said to clearly support that proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “It is well settled that a judgment awarding alimony or a division of marital property which is supported by findings necessary to sustain it will not be set aside unless those findings are ‘plainly wrong.’ King v. King, 373 Mass. 37, 40 (1977). Angelone v. Angelone, supra at 729.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261	663 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts case law consistently applies this two-part test. See, e.g.:
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The proposition refers to a "two-part test" in Massachusetts relocation law, which in context is the Yannas test (good, sincere reason/real advantage plus overall best interests considering specified factors). Rosenthal explicitly applies that two-part Yannas framework, discussing first whether the mother has a good, sincere reason evidencing a real advantage, and then assessing the collective best-interests factors from Yannas and Hale. Thus, it is properly cited as an example of Massachusetts courts consistently applying that two-part test.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: A request for removal is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30, as that statute has been interpreted by Yannas, 395 Mass. at 710, and Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815 (1981). … In weighing the factors to be considered, “the first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’” Yannas, supra at 711. … “If the custodial parent establishes a good, sincere reason for wanting to remove to another jurisdiction, none of the relevant factors becomes controlling in deciding the best interests of the child, but rather they must be considered collectively.” Id. at 711-712.

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: Massachusetts statutes further require that in any custody or visitation proceeding where abuse is alleged, the Court must consider evidence of abuse and the safety of the child.
